thread.title: U.S. men lose; road to Olympics gets tougher
thread.title_full: U.S. men lose; road to Olympics gets tougher

author: Seattle Times staff
title: U.S. men lose; road to Olympics gets tougher
text:
U.S. men lose; road to Olympics gets tougher   7:42 pm Updated October 10, 2015 at 7:46 pm Diego Reyes, left, of Mexico and Jermaine Jones compete for the ball during Saturday night’s CONCACAF Cup match at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif. (Jae C. Hong/AP) The United States is in danger of missing its second straight men’s Olympic soccer tournament. Alberth Elis scored in the 24th and 77th minutes, and Honduras beat the U.S. team 2-0 in Sandy, Utah, to qualify for next year’s Rio de Janeiro Games. By Seattle Times staff The Associated Press 
SANDY, Utah – The United States is in danger of missing its second straight men’s Olympic soccer tournament. 
Alberth Elis scored in the 24th and 77th minutes, and Honduras beat the U.S. team 2-0 Saturday to qualify for next year’s Rio de Janeiro Games in Brazil. 
To reach the Olympics for the first time since 2008, the United States must beat Canada on Tuesday in the third-place match of North and Central American and Caribbean qualifying, then defeat Colombia in the CONCACAF-South America one-game playoff, to be held in Rio in March. 
“We have to win,” U.S. midfielder Wil Trapp said. “Plain and simple. That’s all it takes. There’s no other way. We can’t read into this result anymore. It’s over — disappointing as it was. We got to move forward.” Most Read Stories Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. 
Olympic qualifying is limited to Under-23 teams, and the United States was eliminated four years ago in the group stage. Senior national-team coach Jurgen Klinsmann said failing to reach the 2012 London Olympics set back the careers of players in that age group, which included Brek Shea, Mix Diskerud and Bill Hamid. 
Now another age group could miss out on the Olympics. Among the American starters were New York Red Bulls defender Matt Miazga; Tottenham under-21 defender Cameron Carter-Vickers; Fulham midfielder Emerson Hyndman; Real Salt Lake midfielder Luis Gil; and Stanford forward Jordan Morris of Mercer Island, who already has scored for the U.S. senior national team. 
“We were not able to deal with the situation today,” U.S. coach Andi Herzog said. “It’s sad, but it’s the truth.” 
Herzog cannot be on the bench for Tuesday’s match after receiving a red card in the 81st minute from referee Jafeth Perea of Panama, who also gave a red to Honduras coach Carlos Tabora. 
Elis put the Hondurans ahead when he lobbed the ball over two defenders and past goalkeeper Ethan Horvath. 
The U.S. had two shots on goal in each half. 
“We had our plan, but we weren’t able to do it in the right way,” Herzog said. “That’s the most disappointing thing.” Note 
• Didier Drogba scored on a 30-yard free kick, Evan Bush made a late diving save and the Montreal Impact beat the host Colorado Rapids 1-0 in Major League Soccer. 
The top six teams in each conference advance to the playoffs. Montreal is sixth in the East, four points ahead of Orlando City. Both teams have two matches left. Seattle Times staff
